fr:title.text: The structure of neighbor Conway signatures

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The structure of neighbor Conway signatures

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The recursive neighborhood algorithm computes neighboring tiles in some iterated deflation of a supertile, and we wish to extend this function to work with the hull of these deflations, i.e. the full set of possible Penrose tilings. It is first useful to consider a binary relation, instead of a function, between Conway signatures.

Given a substitution system, two infinite Conway signatures \Sigma _1, \Sigma _2, and an edge label \epsilon _1, \epsilon _2 for each signature, we define a neighborhood relation, denoted as \Sigma _1 \xrightleftharpoons [\epsilon _2]{\epsilon _1} \Sigma _2. It holds if and only if, for every natural number n, there exists finite signatures \Sigma '_1, \Sigma '_2 that agree with \Sigma _1 and \Sigma _2 at the first n places, and the recursive neighborhood algorithm sends (\Sigma '_1, \epsilon _1) to (\Sigma '_2, \epsilon _2).
Note that this relation is symmetric, but not necessarily total or functional.

Essentially the definition says that, if you look at a finite patch of tiles, it is always plausible that this can (hence the \exists quantifier, not \forall ) be extended to a larger patch where they are neighbors in an iterated deflation of one single tile. This also leaves open the possibility that there may be multiple different possible Conway signatures for a neighbor, which is why we opted to consider a binary relation, instead of a function.
Next, we need some general theory relating these infinite objects to finite ones. For this we make some definitions.

Consider the alphabet \Delta where each symbol is either of the form (\text {tile label }t, \text {edge label of }t) or (\text {tile label }t, \text {subtile label of }t). We define a language \mathcal {L} on \Delta \times \Delta , representing a binary relation on \Delta ^* between words of the same length. Let \Sigma = t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} \cdots \xrightarrow {s_n} t_n be a finite Conway signature and \epsilon be an edge label of the corresponding tile. We regard this as a word (t_0, \epsilon )(t_1, s_1) \cdots (t_n, s_n) over the alphabet \Delta . Suppose the recursive neighborhood algorithm sends (\Sigma _1, \epsilon _1) to (\Sigma _2, \epsilon _2), then the two corresponding words can be zipped together to form a word over \Delta \times \Delta . We define the set of all such words as the language of neighborhood relation \mathcal {L}.

Furthermore, consider the set of tile labels \mathrm {T}. We define another language \mathcal {L}^+, called the augmented language of neighborhood relation, over the alphabet (\Delta \times \Delta ) \sqcup \mathrm {T}. Notice that if the recursive neighborhood algorithm sends (\Sigma _1, \epsilon _1) to (\Sigma _2, \epsilon _2), the two signatures always share the last prototile label t_n. We append the symbol t_n to the corresponding word in \mathcal {L}, and define \mathcal {L}^+ to be all the words of this form.

We define the augmented language in this way because it has a very important property, which will be useful later. With this definition in hand, we see that can be defined in terms of a well-known construction in \omega -languages, i.e. languages with infinitely long words.

Given an alphabet \Sigma and a language \mathcal {L} \subseteq \Sigma ^*, its limit is an \omega -language \lim \mathcal {L} \subseteq \Sigma ^\omega containing the words w such that there are infinitely many finite prefixes of w belonging to \mathcal {L}.

We see that the limit of prefixes \operatorname {prfx}\mathcal {L}, or equivalently that of \operatorname {prfx}\mathcal {L}^+ is exactly the neighborhood relation on infinite Conway signatures. Limits are nice because they can be recognized by deterministic finite state machines (also known as deterministic Büchi machines, to emphasize they are for \omega -languages).

fr:title.text: Limits of regular languages are deterministic Büchi recognizable

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits of regular languages are deterministic Büchi recognizable

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a regular language \mathcal {L}, its limit \lim \mathcal {L} can be recognized by a deterministic Büchi automaton, by simply regarding a DFA for \mathcal {L} as a Büchi automaton. In fact, every deterministic Büchi recognizable \omega -language is of this form.

If \mathcal {L} is recognized by an automata, then \operatorname {prfx}\mathcal {L} is recognized by an automata with every state declared to be accepting. This paired with gives a nice construction of a Büchi automata that recognizes neighborhood relations. Now, there is one single hypothesis that I am not able to get rid of. It doesn’t even need a constructive proof, as we will later give a construction that provably satisfies the hypothesis given that it is true.
For any substitution system, the language of neighborhood relation is regular.

Assume we have a substitution system with unique inflation. For a tile t in a tiling, we can inflate the tiling to find t as a subtile in an inflated tile t_1. If we give a unique number to each subtile in a substitution system, we can write this as t \xrightarrow {n_1} t_1, meaning t is the n_1-th subtile. This process can be repeated, generating an infinite path \Sigma = t \xrightarrow {n_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {n_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots where t, t_1, t_2, \dots are prototile labels, and n_i are subtile labels. This path \Sigma is called the Conway signature of the tile. We will also consider the case of a finite patch of tiling, in which case the Conway signature will be a finite path.

Suppose we have a substitution system. Given the Conway signature of a tile t and an edge label \epsilon of that tile, we can calculate the signature of the neighboring tile t' and the edge label \epsilon ' of t' that coincides with \epsilon . This is implemented by mutual recursion with another auxiliary function. Given the signature of a tile and a subedge of that tile under deflation, it calculates the signature of the subtile t' we will arrive in if we cross the subedge inwards, and the edge label of t' corresponding to the input subedge.
This second function is non-trivial, because for some substitution systems, crossing inwards through a subedge may lead us immediately out through another subedge, if they are pinched together. See .

The neighborhood function is as follows. Suppose we have a Conway signature t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots and an edge \epsilon _0 of the tile t_0. We consult the pairing of edges as specified in the substitution system. This has two cases.

fr:ul.fr:li: Suppose the edge \epsilon _0 (of the subtile labelled s_1) is paired with another edge \epsilon '_0 of the subtile numbered s'_1. Then since these two subtiles are neighbors already, we can directly output the signature t'_0 \xrightarrow {s'_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots and the edge label \epsilon '_0, where t'_0 is the prototile type of the s'_1 subtile in t_1.

Suppose the edge is paired with a subedge \sigma _1 of an edge \epsilon _1 in the tile t_1. Then we need to exit the tile t_1 through this edge. We recursively call this function on the Conway signature t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} \cdots and the edge label \epsilon _1. Suppose the algorithm determines that its neighbor has the Conway signature \Delta and the edge label \epsilon '_1. We then invoke the auxiliary function to calculate the subtile we would obtain if we enter \Delta from the subedge \sigma _1 of its edge \epsilon '_1, and we can return its output, tail-recursively.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For the auxiliary function, suppose again we have a signature \Sigma = t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \xrightarrow {s_2} t_2 \longrightarrow \cdots and we have specified an edge \epsilon _0 of the tile t_0, together with one of its subedges \sigma _0. Again, we look up what is paired, in the substitution of t_0, with the subedge \sigma _0.

fr:ul.fr:li: Suppose the result is an edge \epsilon _{-1} in the subtile s_0 of t_0. Then we can output t_{-1} \xrightarrow {s_{0}} t_0 \xrightarrow {s_1} t_1 \longrightarrow \cdots and the edge label \epsilon _{-1}, where t_{-1} is the prototile label corresponding to the subtile s_0.

Suppose the result is another subedge \sigma '_0 of the edge \epsilon '_0. Then we call the neighborhood function on the Conway signature \Sigma and the edge label \epsilon '_0. Let the result be the signature \Delta and the edge \epsilon ''_0. Now we just need to call the auxiliary function on \Delta with the subedge \sigma '_0 of \epsilon ''_0, and return its result.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If we are dealing with finite Conway signatures, then the algorithm should raise an exception if at any point the path is too short. This signals that it has reached the boundary of the finite patch of tiles. Otherwise, the neighborhood function should always output a Conway path of equal length.

Given a tile system, a substitution system is a map from each prototile to a patch of tiles, such that when we replace each tile in a tiling with the substitution, the resulting patches of tiles can fit together in the same way, forming another tiling. This process is called deflation, while the inverse process, if it exists, is called inflation. We usually only consider substitution systems where inflation exists and is unique.

More precisely, given a prototile t, we assign a list of deflated tiles t_i. Each edge of t will be subdivided into several subedges (with their own colors), such that the subdivision only depends on the color, and edges of opposite colors are divided in a way such that the resulting subedges match. For the data of how the deflated tiles glue together, we have a perfect pairing on the set \{\text {subedges of $t$}\} \sqcup \coprod _i \{\text {edges of $t_i$}\} such that the paired edges are compatible. Specifically, if two edges of deflated tiles, or two subedges of t are matched, they must be of opposite colors; if an edge of a deflated tile is matched with a subedge, they must share colors.
In addition to this, the subdivision must also match geometrically, but we shall not give its full definition here, as it suffices to recognize this intuitively.

For convenience, if two edges \epsilon and \epsilon ' have opposite colors, we use the same label for their subedges in a substitution. This simplifies the presentation since we avoid using a conversion look-up table, but requires us to be somewhat careful in assigning labels. In general, we can assign the subedge labels counterclockwise for edges with positive colors, and clockwise for negative colors.
